Standard Description: Count to 100 by ones and by tens.
Strand: Know number names and the count sequence.

Standard Description: Count forward beginning from a given number within the known sequence (instead of having to begin at 1).
Strand: Know number names and the count sequence.

Standard Description: Write numbers from 0 to 20. Represent a number of objects with a written numeral 0-20 (with 0 representing a count of no objects).
Strand: Know number names and the count sequence.

Standard Description: Understand the relationship between numbers and quantities; connect counting to cardinality.
Strand: Count to tell the number of objects.

Standard Description: When counting objects, say the number names in the standard order, pairing each object with one and only one number name and each number name with one and only one object.
Strand: Count to tell the number of objects.

Standard Description: Understand that the last number name said tells the number of objects counted. The number of objects is the same regardless of their arrangement or the order in which they were counted.
Strand: Count to tell the number of objects.

Standard Description: Understand that each successive number name refers to a quantity that is one larger.
Strand: Count to tell the number of objects.

Standard Description: Count to answer “how many?” questions about as many as 20 things arranged in a line, a rectangular array, or a circle, or as many as 10 things in a scattered configuration; given a number from 1–20, count out that many objects.
Strand: Count to tell the number of objects.

Standard Description: Identify whether the number of objects in one group is greater than, less than, or equal to the number of objects in another group, e.g., by using matching and counting strategies.
Strand: Compare numbers.

Standard Description: Compare two numbers between 1 and 10 presented as written numerals.
Strand: Compare numbers.

Standard Description: Represent addition and subtraction with objects, fingers, mental images, drawings
Strand: Understand addition, and understand subtraction.

Standard Description: Solve addition and subtraction word problems, and add and subtract within 10, e.g., by using objects or drawings to represent the problem.
Strand: Understand addition, and understand subtraction.

Standard Description: Decompose numbers less than or equal to 10 into pairs in more than one way, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record each decomposition by a drawing or equation (e.g., 5 = 2 + 3 and 5 = 4 + 1).
Strand: Understand addition, and understand subtraction.

Standard Description: For any number from 1 to 9, find the number that makes 10 when added to the given number, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record the answer with a drawing or equation.
Strand: Understand addition, and understand subtraction.

Standard Description: Fluently add and subtract within 5.
Strand: Understand addition, and understand subtraction.

Standard Description: Compose and decompose numbers from 11 to 19 into ten ones and some further ones, e.g., by using objects or drawings, and record each composition or decomposition by a drawing or equation (such as 18 = 10 + 8); understand that these numbers are composed of ten ones and one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine ones.
Strand: Work with numbers 11-19 to gain foundations for place value.

Standard Description: Describe measurable attributes of objects, such as length or weight. Describe several measurable attributes of a single object.
Strand: Describe and compare measurable attributes.

Standard Description: Directly compare two objects with a measurable attribute in common, to see which object has “more of”/“less of” the attribute, and describe the difference.
Strand: Describe and compare measurable attributes.

Standard Description: Classify objects into given categories; count the numbers of objects in each category and sort the categories by count.
Strand: Classify objects and count the number of objects in each category.

Strand: Identify and describe shapes.

Standard Description: Correctly name shapes regardless of their orientations or overall size.
Strand: Identify and describe shapes.

Standard Description: Identify shapes as two-dimensional (lying in a plane, “flat”) or three-dimensional (“solid”).
Strand: Identify and describe shapes.

Standard Description: Analyze and compare two- and three-dimensional shapes, in different sizes and orientations, using informal language to describe their similarities, differences, parts (e.g., number of sides and vertices/“corners”) and other attributes (e.g., having sides of equal length).
Strand: Analyze, compare, create, and compose shapes.

Standard Description: Model shapes in the world by building shapes from components (e.g., sticks and clay balls) and drawing shapes.
Strand: Analyze, compare, create, and compose shapes.

Standard Description: Compose simple shapes to form larger shapes.
Strand: Analyze, compare, create, and compose shapes.

Standard Description: Use addition and subtraction within 20 to solve word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Strand: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

Standard Description: Solve word problems that call for addition of three whole numbers whose sum is less than or equal to 20, e.g., by using objects, drawings, and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Strand: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

Standard Description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to add and subtract.
Strand: Understand and apply properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

Standard Description: Understand subtraction as an unknown-addend problem.
Strand: Understand and apply properties of operations and the relationship between addition and subtraction.

Standard Description: Relate counting to addition and subtraction (e.g., by counting on 2 to add 2).
Strand: Add and subtract within 20.

Standard Description: Add and subtract within 20, demonstrating fluency for addition and subtraction within 10. Use strategies such as counting on; making ten (e.g., 8 + 6 = 8 + 2 + 4 = 10 + 4 = 14); decomposing a number leading to a ten (e.g., 13 – 4 = 13 – 3 – 1 = 10 – 1 = 9); using the relationship between addition and subtraction (e.g., knowing that 8 + 4 = 12, one knows 12 – 8 = 4); and creating equivalent but easier or known sums (e.g., adding 6 + 7 by creating the known equivalent 6 + 6 + 1 = 12 + 1 = 13).
Strand: Add and subtract within 20.

Standard Description: Understand the meaning of the equal sign, and determine if equations involving addition and subtraction are true or false. For example, which of the following equations are true and which are false? 6 = 6, 7 = 8 – 1, 5 + 2 = 2 + 5, 4 + 1 = 5 + 2.
Strand: Work with addition and subtraction equations.

Standard Description: Determine the unknown whole number in an addition or subtraction equation relating three whole numbers.
Strand: Work with addition and subtraction equations.

Standard Description: Count to 120, starting at any number less than 120. In this range, read and write numerals and represent a number of objects with a written numeral.
Strand: Extend the counting sequence.

Standard Description: Understand that the two digits of a two-digit number represent amounts of tens and ones. Understand the following as special cases:
Strand: Understand place value.

Standard Description: 10 can be thought of as a bundle of ten ones  -  called a “ten.”
Strand: Understand place value.

Standard Description: The numbers from 11 to 19 are composed of a ten and one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine ones.
Strand: Understand place value.

Standard Description: The numbers 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80, 90 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine tens (and 0 ones).
Strand: Understand place value.

Standard Description: Compare two two-digit numbers based on meanings of the tens and ones digits, recording the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, and <.
Strand: Understand place value.

Standard Description: Add within 100, including adding a two-digit number and a one-digit number, and adding a two-digit number and a multiple of 10, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used. Understand that in adding two-digit numbers, one adds tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary to compose a ten.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.

Standard Description: Given a two-digit number, mentally find 10 more or 10 less than the number, without having to count; explain the reasoning used.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.

Standard Description: Subtract multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 from multiples of 10 in the range 10-90 (positive or zero differences), using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method and explain the reasoning used.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.

Standard Description: Order three objects by length; compare the lengths of two objects indirectly by using a third object.
Strand: Measure lengths indirectly and by iterating length units.

Standard Description: Express the length of an object as a whole number of length units, by laying multiple copies of a shorter object (the length unit) end to end; understand that the length measurement of an object is the number of same-size length units that span it with no gaps or overlaps.
Strand: Measure lengths indirectly and by iterating length units.

Standard Description: Tell and write time in hours and half-hours using analog and digital clocks.
Strand: Tell and write time.

Standard Description: Organize, represent, and interpret data with up to three categories; ask and answer questions about the total number of data points, how many in each category, and how many more or less are in one category than in another.
Strand: Represent and interpret data.

Standard Description: Distinguish between defining attributes (e.g., triangles are closed and three-sided) versus non-defining attributes (e.g., color, orientation, overall size) ; build and draw shapes to possess defining attributes.
Strand: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

Standard Description: Compose two-dimensional shapes (rectangles, squares, trapezoids, triangles, half-circles, and quarter-circles) or three-dimensional shapes (cubes, right rectangular prisms, right circular cones, and right circular cylinders) to create a composite shape, and compose new shapes from the composite shape
Strand: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

Standard Description: Partition circles and rectangles into two and four equal shares, describe the shares using the words
Strand: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

Standard Description: Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve one- and two-step word problems involving situations of adding to, taking from, putting together, taking apart, and comparing, with unknowns in all positions, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Strand: Represent and solve problems involving addition and subtraction.

Standard Description: Fluently add and subtract within 20 using mental strategies.
Strand: Add and subtract within 20.

Standard Description: Determine whether a group of objects (up to 20) has an odd or even number of members, e.g., by pairing objects or counting them by 2s; write an equation to express an even number as a sum of two equal addends.
Strand: Work with equal groups of objects to gain foundations for multiplication.

Standard Description: Use addition to find the total number of objects arranged in rectangular arrays with up to 5 rows and up to 5 columns; write an equation to express the total as a sum of equal addends.
Strand: Work with equal groups of objects to gain foundations for multiplication.

Standard Description: Understand that the three digits of a three-digit number represent amounts of hundreds, tens, and ones; e.g., 706 equals 7 hundreds, 0 tens, and 6 ones. Understand the following as special cases:
Strand: Understand place value.

Standard Description: 100 can be thought of as a bundle of ten tens  -  called a “hundred.”
Strand: Understand place value.

Standard Description: The numbers 100, 200, 300, 400, 500, 600, 700, 800, 900 refer to one, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, or nine hundreds (and 0 tens and 0 ones).
Strand: Understand place value.

Standard Description: Count within 1000; skip-count by 5s, 10s, and 100s.
Strand: Understand place value.

Standard Description: Read and write numbers to 1000 using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form.
Strand: Understand place value.

Standard Description: Compare two three-digit numbers based on meanings of the hundreds, tens, and ones digits, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Strand: Understand place value.

Standard Description: Fluently add and subtract within 100 using strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.

Standard Description: Add up to four two-digit numbers using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.

Standard Description: Add and subtract within 1000, using concrete models or drawings and strategies based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction; relate the strategy to a written method. Understand that in adding or subtracting three-digit numbers, one adds or subtracts hundreds and hundreds, tens and tens, ones and ones; and sometimes it is necessary to compose or decompose tens or hundreds.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.

Standard Description: Mentally add 10 or 100 to a given number 100–900, and mentally subtract 10 or 100 from a given number 100–900.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.

Standard Description: Explain why addition and subtraction strategies work, using place value and the properties of operations.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to add and subtract.

Standard Description: Measure the length of an object by selecting and using appropriate tools such as rulers, yardsticks, meter sticks, and measuring tapes.
Strand: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

Standard Description: Measure the length of an object twice, using length units of different lengths for the two measurements; describe how the two measurements relate to the size of the unit chosen.
Strand: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

Standard Description: Estimate lengths using units of inches, feet, centimeters, and meters.
Strand: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

Standard Description: Measure to determine how much longer one object is than another, expressing the length difference in terms of a standard length unit.
Strand: Measure and estimate lengths in standard units.

Standard Description: Use addition and subtraction within 100 to solve word problems involving lengths that are given in the same units, e.g., by using drawings (such as drawings of rulers) and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Strand: Relate addition and subtraction to length.

Standard Description: Represent whole numbers as lengths from 0 on a number line diagram with equally spaced points corresponding to the numbers 0, 1, 2, ..., and represent whole-number sums and differences within 100 on a number line diagram.
Strand: Relate addition and subtraction to length.

Standard Description: Tell and write time from analog and digital clocks to the nearest five minutes, using a.m. and p.m.
Strand: Work with time and money.

Standard Description: Solve word problems involving dollar bills, quarters, dimes, nickels, and pennies, using $ and ¢ symbols appropriately. Example: If you have 2 dimes and 3 pennies, how many cents do you have?
Strand: Work with time and money.

Standard Description: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths of several objects to the nearest whole unit, or by making repeated measurements of the same object. Show the measurements by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in whole-number units.
Strand: Represent and interpret data.

Standard Description: Draw a picture graph and a bar graph (with single-unit scale) to represent a data set with up to four categories. Solve simple put-together, take-apart, and compare problems
Strand: Represent and interpret data.

Standard Description: Recognize and draw shapes having specified attributes, such as a given number of angles or a given number of equal faces.
Strand: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

Standard Description: Partition a rectangle into rows and columns of same-size squares and count to find the total number of them.
Strand: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

Standard Description: Partition circles and rectangles into two, three, or four equal shares, describe the shares using the words halves, thirds, half of, a third of, etc., and describe the whole as two halves, three thirds, four fourths. Recognize that equal shares of identical wholes need not have the same shape.
Strand: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

Standard Description: Interpret products of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 5 × 7 as the total number of objects in 5 groups of 7 objects each.
Strand: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.

Standard Description: Interpret whole-number quotients of whole numbers, e.g., interpret 56 ÷ 8 as the number of objects in each share when 56 objects are partitioned equally into 8 shares, or as a number of shares when 56 objects are partitioned into equal shares of 8 objects each.
Strand: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.

Standard Description: Use multiplication and division within 100 to solve word problems in situations involving equal groups, arrays, and measurement quantities, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem.
Strand: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.

Standard Description: Determine the unknown whole number in a multiplication or division equation relating three whole numbers.
Strand: Represent and solve problems involving multiplication and division.

Standard Description: Apply properties of operations as strategies to multiply and divide.
Strand: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.

Standard Description: Understand division as an unknown-factor problem.
Strand: Understand properties of multiplication and the relationship between multiplication and division.

Standard Description: Fluently multiply and divide within 100, using strategies such as the relationship between multiplication and division (e.g., knowing that 8 × 5 = 40, one knows 40 ÷ 5 = 8) or properties of operations. By the end of Grade 3, know from memory all products of two one-digit numbers.
Strand: Multiply and divide within 100.

Standard Description: Solve two-step word problems using the four operations. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
Strand: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.

Standard Description: Identify arithmetic patterns (including patterns in the addition table or multiplication table), and explain them using properties of operations.
Strand: Solve problems involving the four operations, and identify and explain patterns in arithmetic.

Standard Description: Use place value understanding to round whole numbers to the nearest 10 or 100.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.1

Standard Description: Fluently add and subtract within 1000 using strategies and algorithms based on place value, properties of operations, and/or the relationship between addition and subtraction.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.1

Standard Description: Multiply one-digit whole numbers by multiples of 10 in the range 10–90 (e.g., 9 × 80, 5 × 60) using strategies based on place value and properties of operations.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.1

Standard Description: Understand a fraction as a number on the number line; represent fractions on a number line diagram.
Strand: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

Strand: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

Standard Description: Represent a fraction
Strand: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

Standard Description: Explain equivalence of fractions in special cases, and compare fractions by reasoning about their size.
Strand: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

Standard Description: Understand two fractions as equivalent (equal) if they are the same size, or the same point on a number line.
Strand: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

Standard Description: Recognize and generate simple equivalent fractions, e.g., 1/2 = 2/4, 4/6 = 2/3). Explain why the fractions are equivalent, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
Strand: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

Standard Description: Express whole numbers as fractions, and recognize fractions that are equivalent to whole numbers.
Strand: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

Standard Description: Compare two fractions with the same numerator or the same denominator by reasoning about their size. Recognize that comparisons are valid only when the two fractions refer to the same whole. Record the results of comparisons with the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions, e.g., by using a visual fraction model.
Strand: Develop understanding of fractions as numbers.

Standard Description: Tell and write time to the nearest minute and measure time intervals in minutes. Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of time intervals in minutes, e.g., by representing the problem on a number line diagram.
Strand: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation.

Standard Description: Measure and estimate liquid volumes and masses of objects using standard units of grams (g), kilograms (kg), and liters (l).
Strand: Solve problems involving measurement and estimation.

Standard Description: Draw a scaled picture graph and a scaled bar graph to represent a data set with several categories. Solve one- and two-step “how many more” and “how many less” problems using information presented in scaled bar graphs.
Strand: Represent and interpret data.

Standard Description: Generate measurement data by measuring lengths using rulers marked with halves and fourths of an inch. Show the data by making a line plot, where the horizontal scale is marked off in appropriate units -  whole numbers, halves, or quarters.
Strand: Represent and interpret data.

Standard Description: Recognize area as an attribute of plane figures and understand concepts of area measurement.
Strand: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

Standard Description: A square with side length 1 unit, called “a unit square,” is said to have “one square unit” of area, and can be used to measure area.
Strand: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

Strand: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

Standard Description: Measure areas by counting unit squares (square cm, square m, square in, square ft, and improvised units).
Strand: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

Standard Description: Relate area to the operations of multiplication and addition.
Strand: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

Standard Description: Find the area of a rectangle with whole-number side lengths by tiling it, and show that the area is the same as would be found by multiplying the side lengths.
Strand: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

Standard Description: Multiply side lengths to find areas of rectangles with whole-number side lengths in the context of solving real world and mathematical problems, and represent whole-number products as rectangular areas in mathematical reasoning.
Strand: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

Strand: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

Standard Description: Recognize area as additive. Find areas of rectilinear figures by decomposing them into non-overlapping rectangles and adding the areas of the non-overlapping parts, applying this technique to solve real world problems.
Strand: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of area and relate area to multiplication and to addition.

Standard Description: Solve real world and mathematical problems involving perimeters of polygons, including finding the perimeter given the side lengths, finding an unknown side length, and exhibiting rectangles with the same perimeter and different areas or with the same area and different perimeters.
Strand: Geometric measurement: recognize perimeter.

Standard Description: Understand that shapes in different categories (e.g., rhombuses, rectangles, and others) may share attributes (e.g., having four sides), and that the shared attributes can define a larger category (e.g., quadrilaterals). Recognize rhombuses, rectangles, and squares as examples of quadrilaterals, and draw examples of quadrilaterals that do not belong to any of these subcategories.
Strand: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

Standard Description: Partition shapes into parts with equal areas. Express the area of each part as a unit fraction of the whole.
Strand: Reason with shapes and their attributes.

Standard Description: Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 × 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.
Strand: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

Standard Description: Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.
Strand: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

Standard Description: Solve multistep word problems posed with whole numbers and having whole-number answers using the four operations, including problems in which remainders must be interpreted. Represent these problems using equations with a letter standing for the unknown quantity. Assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies including rounding.
Strand: Use the four operations with whole numbers to solve problems.

Standard Description: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1–100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1–100 is prime or composite.
Strand: Gain familiarity with factors and multiples.

Standard Description: Generate a number or shape pattern that follows a given rule. Identify apparent features of the pattern that were not explicit in the rule itself.
Strand: Generate and analyze patterns.

Standard Description: Recognize that in a multi-digit whole number, a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right.
Strand: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.

Standard Description: Read and write multi-digit whole numbers using base-ten numerals, number names, and expanded form. Compare two multi-digit numbers based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols to record the results of comparisons.
Strand: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.

Standard Description: Use place value understanding to round multi-digit whole numbers to any place.
Strand: Generalize place value understanding for multi-digit whole numbers.

Standard Description: Fluently add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers using the standard algorithm.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.

Standard Description: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.

Standard Description: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Strand: Use place value understanding and properties of operations to perform multi-digit arithmetic.

Strand: Extend understanding of fraction equivalence and ordering.

Strand: Build fractions from unit fractions

Strand: Build fractions from unit fractions

Standard Description: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole and having like denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Strand: Build fractions from unit fractions

Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication to multiply a fraction by a whole number.
Strand: Build fractions from unit fractions

Strand: Build fractions from unit fractions

Standard Description: Understand a multiple of a/b as a multiple of 1/b, and use this understanding to multiply a fraction by a whole number.
Strand: Build fractions from unit fractions

Standard Description: Solve word problems involving multiplication of a fraction by a whole number, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Strand: Build fractions from unit fractions

Standard Description: Express a fraction with denominator 10 as an equivalent fraction with denominator 100, and use this technique to add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100.
Strand: Understand decimal notation for fractions, and compare decimal fractions.

Standard Description: Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100.
Strand: Understand decimal notation for fractions, and compare decimal fractions.

Strand: Understand decimal notation for fractions, and compare decimal fractions.

Standard Description: Know relative sizes of measurement units within one system of units including km, m, cm; kg, g; lb, oz.; l, ml; hr, min, sec. Within a single system of measurement, express measurements in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Record measurement equivalents in a two-column table.
Strand: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements.

Standard Description: Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams that feature a measurement scale.
Strand: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements.

Standard Description: Apply the area and perimeter formulas for rectangles in real world and mathematical problems.
Strand: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements.

Standard Description: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (1/2, 1/4, 1/8). Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots.
Strand: Represent and interpret data.

Strand: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

Standard Description: Recognize angle measure as additive. When an angle is decomposed into non-overlapping parts, the angle measure of the whole is the sum of the angle measures of the parts. Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real world and mathematical problems, e.g., by using an equation with a symbol for the unknown angle measure.
Strand: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle and measure angles.

Standard Description: Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
Strand: Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.
